description.narrative: FAIR for ALL will focus on improving the livelihoods and opportunities of hundreds of millions small-scale producers, artisanal miners, (informal) plantation workers in exploitative primary-commodity value chains, in particular agriculture and minerals, and their communities. FAIR for ALL has a specific focus on grassroots women; given their innovative power to co-create solutions that respond to challenges they face in their day to day lives, and their expanding role in global agriculture, investment in them represents a key opportunity for raising incomes across developing countries. Their economic empowerment also requires addressing patriarchy and social norms which exclude women from value chains and decision-making processes.

Participation in global trade and local, global and regional value chains has provided many opportunities for countries to achieve progress towards the SDGs. Over the last three decades, it has grown economies, raised productivity, created jobs and increased incomes. One billion people have escaped poverty, mostly through improved access to markets. However, global trade and value chains have emerged alongside increased concentration of power and wealth in the hands of a few hundred companies and their financiers, at the expense of hundreds of millions of people. Trade rules have been developed to serve narrow commercial interests, resulting in rich countries and powerful corporations capturing a disproportionate share of the benefits. Therefore, the FAIR for ALL consortium – comprising Oxfam Novib, Huairou Commission, SOMO and Third World Network-Africa (TWN-Africa) – will support people in their collaboration with, and rightful demands towards companies, governments and multilateral organizations for economic, social and environmental justice, promoting global trade and value-chains that are FAIR for ALL.

Strategic objective: A strengthened civil society which is capable of creating space and mobilizing people across geographies to demand and contribute to more inclusive and sustainable trade and value chains that respect human rights, protect the environment and promote women’s economic empowerment.
Outcomes: - Pathway 1 strengthens civil society to co-create alternative business practices which share value more equally and empower women. - Pathway 3 strengthens civil society to advocate for more accountable governments, multilateral institutions and regulatory frameworks – that is, for governments to effectively regulate the private sector.
